g.text: client
server
client
server
client:
• supports mTLS authentication with X.509 certificates
• uses a self-signed or CA-signed certificate with a certificate extension containing a custom OID and
ASN1:UTF8String value that serves as a global client identifier in respect of the service it represents,
e.g., 1.2.3.4.5.6.7.8=ASN1:UTF8String:client._mhs._grip.foo.com
• the client's public key hash is published on the client domain using DNS TXT record,
e.g., client._mhs._grip.foo.com IN TXT "v=grip1; h=sha256; p=d2abde240d7cd3ee6b ... e971"
server:
• supports mTLS authentication with X.509 certificates
• uses a CA-signed certificate with an appropriate Subject Alternative Name (SAN)
• uses a DNS SRV record to specify a host and port of the server, while identifies the respective
service, e.g., _mhs._tcp.bar.com
• uses the information in the assertion to identify the user and makes authorization decisions
using a placeholder message that servers as an access control list
1. the client generates a token — a signed, using the client's private key,
DNS-bound assertion in JWT format with these claims:
{iss, aud, sub, exp, nbf, jwk, act{sub}, tokens}
• iss identifies who issues the token — CN from public client's certificate,
e.g., foo.com
• aud identifies the target service by the DNS SRV record, e.g., _mhs._tcp.bar.com
• sub identifies the user by email address,
e.g. User Principal Name (UPN) from Active Directory (AD)
(client impersonates the user by using their email address)
• exp, nbf are the standard JWT claims
• jwks holds a client's certificate public key in the JWK Set format
(alternatively provide JWK Set by URI using jwks_uri claim)
• tokens (optional) holds an embedded JWT from the previous hop
• fingerprint (optional) contains a fingerprint of the data being transmitted
2. Send an HTTPS request to the server with the token using mTLS
3. Authorization decision
• the client is authenticated via the DNS using the TXT record and the custom OID value
from the public client's certificate
• verify the token signature
• validate proof-of-possession
• verify the aud claim
• (optional) evaluate embedded tokens
• the domain part of the author's email address or one of the recipient's email addresses
listed in the placeholder message and the domain part of the custom OID value from
the public client's certificate must match
• check that the user's email address is listed in the placeholder message
4. Return the HTTP response, typically with 200, 201 status code
